title: Richard Devon
text:
Richard Devon (born Richard Gibson Ferraiole, December 11, 1926 – February 26, 2010) was an American <a href="character%20actor">character actor</a> and <a href="Voice%20acting">voice actor</a> who between the late 1940s and 1991 performed in hundreds of roles on stage, radio, television, and in feature films.
Early life.
Devon was born in <a href="Glendale%2C%20California">Glendale, California</a> in 1926, the only son of four children of Florence H. (née Glass) and Luca Ferraiole. His father, a native of Italy, immigrated to the United States in 1901 and lived in Pennsylvania before moving to California, where by 1930 he was employed as a waiter in a Los Angeles cafe. To supplement his family's modest income, Devon later worked part-time as a stable boy and then as a riding instructor at an <a href="Equestrianism">equestrian</a> academy in <a href="Griffith%20Park">Griffith Park</a>. That early experience with horses proved useful in his acting career, especially in <a href="Western%20%28genre%29">Western</a> films and television series. Following his graduation from high school, Devon worked as a mail carrier at <a href="Monogram%20Pictures">Monogram Pictures</a>, a laborer at a plant <a href="plant%20nursery">nursery</a>, a mechanic's helper, and as a <a href="Bouncer%20%28doorman%29">doorman</a> at the <a href="Hollywood%20Palladium">Hollywood Palladium</a>.
Career.
In the 1950s Devon began performing as a character actor in many <a href="Four%20Star%20Television">Four Star Television</a> series, although his work was not limited to a single production company or network. He appears, for example, as Ed Pike in the 1959 episode "Yellow Fever" of the <a href="Western%20%28genre%29">Western</a> series "<a href="Colt%20.45%20%28TV%20series%29">Colt .45</a>", which was produced by <a href="Warner%20Bros.">Warner Bros.</a> and originally broadcast by <a href="American%20Broadcasting%20Company">ABC</a>.
Devon's television credits include "<a href="Richard%20Diamond%2C%20Private%20Detective">Richard Diamond, Private Detective</a>" (three episodes), "<a href="The%20Rifleman">The Rifleman</a>", "<a href="Tales%20of%20Wells%20Fargo">Tales of Wells Fargo</a>", "<a href="The%20Life%20and%20Legend%20of%20Wyatt%20Earp">The Life and Legend of Wyatt Earp</a>", "<a href="Johnny%20Ringo%20%28TV%20series%29">Johnny Ringo</a>" (in the episode "The Posse"), "<a href="Space%20Patrol%20%281950%20TV%20series%29">Space Patrol</a>", "<a href="Trackdown%20%28TV%20series%29">Trackdown</a>" starring <a href="Robert%20Culp">Robert Culp</a> (three episodes, including the <a href="Television%20pilot">pilot</a> episode of that series, "Badge of Honor," which aired initially on "<a href="Dick%20Powell%27s%20Zane%20Grey%20Theatre">Dick Powell's Zane Grey Theatre</a>"), "<a href="The%20Tall%20Man%20%28TV%20series%29">The Tall Man</a>", "<a href="Gunsmoke%20%28TV%20series%29">Gunsmoke</a>" (in the episodes "Ex-Con" and "The Quest for Asa Janin"), "<a href="Highway%20Patrol%20%28American%20TV%20series%29">Highway Patrol</a>" as a hitchhiker, "<a href="The%20Rebel%20%28American%20TV%20series%29">The Rebel</a>", "<a href="The%20Virginian%20%28TV%20series%29">The Virginian</a>" (as Haskell in the 1970 episode "You Can Lead a Horse to Water") and its <a href="Spin-off%20%28media%29">spin-off</a>, "<a href="Bonanza">Bonanza</a>" (four episodes from 1960-1967: "The Avenger", "The Trail Gang", "The Scapegoat" and "A Bride for Buford"), "<a href="Laredo%20%28TV%20series%29">Laredo</a>", "<a href="Daniel%20Boone%20%281964%20TV%20series%29">Daniel Boone</a>", "<a href="The%20Monkees%20%28TV%20series%29">The Monkees</a>", "<a href="Lassie%20%281954%20TV%20series%29">Lassie</a>", "<a href="The%20Twilight%20Zone%20%281959%20TV%20series%29">The Twilight Zone</a>" episode "Dead Man's Shoes" in 1962, three episodes of "<a href="Perry%20Mason%20%281957%20TV%20series%29">Perry Mason</a>" from 1964–1966, and "". Devon had a regular role as well as on the <a href="CBS">CBS</a> series "<a href="Yancy%20Derringer">Yancy Derringer</a>", performing the part of Jody Barker, a <a href="Pickpocketing">pickpocket</a> and sometime cohort of the lead character played by <a href="Jock%20Mahoney">Jock Mahoney</a>. He also played the role of Cole Striker, a crook, in the 1963 episode "Incident of the Buryin' Man" on CBS's "<a href="Rawhide%20%28TV%20series%29">Rawhide</a>".
He provided the voice of <a href="Batman">Batman</a> on episodes of the radio version of "<a href="The%20Adventures%20of%20Superman%20%28radio%20series%29">The Adventures of Superman</a>".
Devon's <a href="feature%20film">big screen</a> career consists of at least two dozen feature films. Some of those productions are "<a href="The%20Undead%20%28film%29">The Undead</a>", "<a href="War%20of%20the%20Satellites">War of the Satellites</a>", "<a href="The%20Three%20Stooges%20Go%20Around%20the%20World%20in%20a%20Daze">The Three Stooges Go Around the World in a Daze</a>", "<a href="The%20Comancheros%20%28film%29">The Comancheros</a>", and the "<a href="Battle%20of%20Blood%20Island">Battle of Blood Island</a>".
Personal life and death.
In December 1959 Devon married Patricia A. Riopelle. They remained together for over 50 years, until Devon died of <a href="vascular%20disease">vascular disease</a> in <a href="Mill%20Valley%2C%20California">Mill Valley, California</a> in 2010.
